transcript:
Therapist: You've done a great job working through this Meta-Thought Record, Jin-Soo. As we've seen, challenging negative thoughts and developing more balanced perspectives can be really helpful in managing self-doubt and hopelessness. Another important aspect of maintaining your progress after therapy is having a solid relapse prevention plan in place. Have you given any thought to what you'd like to include in your plan?

Patient: I've been thinking about it, but I'm not entirely sure what should be included in a relapse prevention plan. Can you give me some guidance on that?

Therapist: Absolutely. A relapse prevention plan is essentially a roadmap for how you'll maintain your progress and cope with any challenges that may arise after therapy ends. It typically includes several key components, such as identifying your personal warning signs that depression may be returning, outlining specific coping strategies you can use when you notice these warning signs, and having a list of supportive people you can reach out to for help. It's also important to include a plan for how you'll continue to practice and apply the skills you've learned in therapy.

Patient: That makes sense. I think one of my warning signs is when I start to isolate myself and avoid social interactions. That's usually a sign that I'm starting to feel down and struggling with negative thoughts.

Therapist: That's a really good insight, Jin-Soo. Avoidance and isolation can definitely be warning signs of depression. What are some coping strategies you could use when you notice yourself starting to isolate?

Patient: I could reach out to a friend or family member, even if it's just a quick phone call or text. I could also try to schedule some social activities, like meeting up with someone from my gardening group or attending a community event.

Therapist: Those are great coping strategies. Reaching out to others and engaging in social activities can be really helpful in combating isolation and improving your mood. Another important aspect of your relapse prevention plan is identifying the skills and techniques from therapy that you want to continue practicing. Which skills have you found most helpful?

Patient: I've found the Meta-Thought Records to be really useful, as well as the behavioral experiments we've done. I also think the Positive Data Log has been helpful for recognizing my progress and accomplishments.

Therapist: It's great that you've identified specific skills that have been helpful for you. Definitely include those in your relapse prevention plan, along with a schedule for when you'll practice them. It can also be helpful to create some coping cards with reminders of the key skills and concepts you've learned, so you have them readily available when you need them.

Patient: That's a good idea. I can create some coping cards with reminders about challenging negative thoughts, engaging in enjoyable activities, and reaching out for support when I need it.

Therapist: Exactly. Having those tangible reminders can be really helpful in moments when you're struggling. Another important aspect of your relapse prevention plan is identifying sources of support. Who are the people in your life that you feel comfortable reaching out to when you need help?

Patient: I have a few close friends and family members that I know I can count on. I also feel supported by the people in my gardening group, even though I don't know them as well.

Therapist: It's great that you have a network of supportive people in your life. Definitely include their names and contact information in your relapse prevention plan, so you have it easily accessible when you need it. It can also be helpful to have a conversation with them about your relapse prevention plan, so they understand how they can best support you.

Patient: That's a good point. I think it would be helpful to talk to my close friends and family about what I've been working on in therapy and how they can support me going forward.

Therapist: Absolutely. Having those open conversations can make it easier to reach out for help when you need it. As we're developing your relapse prevention plan, it's also important to consider how you'll handle any setbacks or challenges that may arise. What are some strategies you can use to cope with setbacks?

Patient: I think it's important to remember that setbacks are a normal part of the process and don't mean that I'm back at square one. I can try to reframe setbacks as opportunities for learning and growth, and use the skills I've learned in therapy to work through them.

Therapist: That's a really healthy and adaptive perspective, Jin-Soo. Setbacks are a normal part of the recovery process, and they don't negate all the progress you've made. Reframing setbacks as opportunities for growth and using your therapy skills to cope with them is a great strategy. It can also be helpful to have a plan for how you'll practice self-care and self-compassion when you're facing a setback.

Patient: Self-care and self-compassion are areas I still struggle with sometimes. I can be pretty hard on myself when things don't go as planned.

Therapist: That's a common challenge, and it's something we can continue to work on. One strategy for practicing self-compassion is to imagine how you would respond to a close friend or loved one who was going through a similar setback. What would you say to them? How would you support them?

Patient: I would probably remind them of their strengths and accomplishments, and encourage them to be kind to themselves. I would let them know that setbacks are temporary and don't define their worth or abilities.

Therapist: That's a beautiful and compassionate response, Jin-Soo. Now, imagine applying that same level of compassion and support to yourself when you're facing a setback. What would that look like?

Patient: It would look like reminding myself of my own strengths and accomplishments, and being gentle with myself instead of self-critical. It would mean acknowledging that setbacks are temporary and don't define my worth or abilities.

Therapist: Exactly. Practicing that same level of self-compassion and support towards yourself is a key part of maintaining your progress and resilience. It's something that takes practice, but it can make a big difference in how you cope with setbacks and challenges.
